Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the violations identified in the report and 2022C0108005, a first provisional license is
recommended, and a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For any repeat violations, why the prior CAP did not result in compliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616) 552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
Staff member shoved youth and held youth down. Staff member was terminated
shortly after for reasons unknown.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received on 12/03/21 and investigated jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. The initial allegations were as follows,
Youth A (15) is a resident at Methodist Children's Home Society. Staff 1 is a staff
member at the residential home. Prior to moving to his current cottage, Staff 1
shoved Youth A and held him down. Staff 1 was fired shortly thereafter this
incident for an unknown reason. It is unknown if there is video evidence of this
incident taking place or not. Youth A was not injured during this incident that is
known. It is unknown as to what was taking place prior to Staff 1 assaulting
Youth A.
Youth A was interviewed at the facility jointly with the DHHS Specialist on 12/06/21.
Youth A reported he was hiding from the Supervisor and was redirected. Youth A
said Staff 1 chimed in and was “talking stuff,” and told Youth A that he would have to
remove items from Youth A’s room if Youth A didn’t come out from hiding. Youth A
said that he “forcibly” went after Staff 1 and pushed Staff 1. Youth A said he did this
because he was going to lose his personal items so “I fight back.” Youth A said Staff
1 shoved him, picked him up by the legs and slammed Youth A on the ground.
Youth A said his arm was behind his own back when this happened, and his arm
was sore for 2 weeks afterward. Youth A said he didn’t tell anyone about this
because he thought he would heal up fast and it did. Youth A said that a
maintenance staff and Staff 2 were around when this occurred, but no kids were
present. Youth A said that Staff 1 and Staff 2 (who is reportedly Staff 1’s father)
restrained him on the floor with his arms spread out and legs together. Youth A said
the Supervisor held his legs and Staffs 1 and 2 held his arms, with Staff 1 putting his
knee on Youth A’s chest. Youth A said Staff 1 was fired shortly after this incident and
Youth A moved out of the shelter and into the residential program. Youth A went on
to report that being at the facility raises his anxiety and he became hyperverbal and
started talking about other, unrelated concerns and wanting to be in another
placement, so needed redirection to stay on topic. Youth A said he doesn’t feel safe
due to peers threatening to hurt him, but he provided no names. Youth A said he
gets hurt regularly by peers and that is why is doesn’t feel safe. Youth A reported no
other concerns with staff at the facility.
Director 2 was interviewed at the facility on 12/06/21, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. Director 2 is the Director of Transitional Housing (Shelter). Director 2
recalled an escalated incident with Youth A at the shelter but did not recall Staff 1
hitting Youth A or holding Youth A down. Director 2 said she processed an incident
with Youth A and Staff 1, but it was nothing like the allegations. Director 2 said there
4

had been a couple of incidents in Youth A’s time at the shelter when he hurt staff.
Director 2 did not know if Staff 2 had been fired. She confirmed that Staff 2 is a
maintenance person and a direct care staff for the residential program but does not
work shifts in the shelter. Director 2 confirmed the Supervisor voluntarily left the
facility.
I interviewed Staff 3 at the facility jointly with the DHHS Specialist on 12/08/21. Staff
3 said that she was working in the shelter and recalled in incident with Youth A being
defiant and escalating into aggression with Staff 1. This was the day Youth A was
hiding and was told to come out and Youth A became verbally aggressive. Staff 3
said that Staff 1 tried to deescalate Youth A, but Youth A went at Staff 1 swinging.
Staff 1 reportedly backed away and tried to calm Youth A verbally. Staff 3 denied
seeing Staff 1 push Youth A or slamming Youth A to the floor. Staff 3 denied
witnessing Staff 1 restrain Youth A, but Staff 3 said she was not in eyesight of the
whole incident as she was watching another youth who was on individual
supervision.
The DHHS Specialist and I interviewed the Chief Administrator (CA), on 12/08/21, at
the facility. The CA reported that to her knowledge, Youth A had assaulted Staff 1.
The CA said she was in the administration building when this occurred. The CA said
that the Supervisor was in the shelter and had called the police because she wanted
Youth A hospitalized. The CA said that Director 2 went to the shelter and kept Youth
A at the facility and the Supervisor was angry with this decision. The CA said that
Director 2 texted her for help because the Supervisor was yelling and swearing. The
CA said that police were already onsite due to a separate event and accompanied
the CA to the shelter. The CA said that on their way from the administration building
to the shelter building, the Supervisor drove past them, left campus, and quit. The
CA said that when she arrived, there were other administrators there and the report
given to her was that Youth A assaulted Staff 1. The CA went on to report that the
month prior, someone sent a news article to the facility human resources department
related to Staff 1’s criminal history. The CA said that all clearances done by the
facility showed Staff 1 as appropriate to work at the facility, however, with the new
information, it was decided that he would be removed from the schedule. Staff 1 has
since been let go from employment as of 11/19/21 as they are an at-will agency. The
CA said that prior to this, Staff 1 was a model staff and very good with the youth.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the facility, on 12/08/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Staff 2 reported that he is the lead maintenance staff and also works as a direct care
staff on a contingent basis in the residential program, but not in the shelter. Staff 1
said that on the day of this incident, he was working as maintenance and was in the
shelter. Staff 2 said Youth A was attacking Staff 1 and was out of control. Staff 2
said that Youth A and Staff 1 were “already in the throes of it when I came in.” Staff
2 denied seeing Staff 1 pick-up Youth A and slam him to the floor. Staff 2 said Staff
1 was protecting himself and put his arms up to hold Youth A in place for a while.
Staff 2 said he helped Staff 1 hold Youth A. Staff 2 said that at one point they were
holding Youth A on the ground, and they were also standing at times. Staff 2 said
5

Staff 1 was “doing the best he could” and noted that Youth A is a lot larger than Staff
1. During the physical management on the floor, Staff 2 said that he held one of
Youth A’s arms down while Staff 1 held the other while Youth A was struggling. Staff
2 said the Supervisor tried to hold Youth A’s legs because Youth A was kicking. Staff
2 said that Youth A and Staff 1 were “tussling.” The Supervisor left after this incident.
Per Staff 2, the Supervisor just got in her car and drove off. Staff 2 said he didn’t
write an incident report and noted that as a maintenance staff, they don’t write
incident reports. Staff 2 said he “never handles situations like this.” The police
arrived as well as other administrative and support staff, but this was after the
incident. Staff 2 said he was trained in CPI physical management but reported that
this was not a CPI restraint. Staff 2 said staff are not allowed to restrain anymore.
Staff 2 confirmed that Staff 1 is his son.
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with the DHHS Specialist on 12/08/21, via phone, as he is
no longer employed with the facility,. Staff 1 recalled the incident and noted that
Youth A had returned from school and was not following directions and then hid
under the desk. Staff 1 and the Supervisor directed Youth A out from under the
desk. The Supervisor then directed Staff 1 to remove Youth A’s personal items from
Youth A’s room. It was at this time that Youth A charged at Staff 1. Staff 1 said this
scared the Supervisor, who was new. Staff 1 said that he stepped away, but Youth A
kept coming at him. Staff 1 said that he and the Supervisor each attempted to
secure an arm, but the Supervisor let go. The maintenance staff then helped Staff 1
secure Youth A. Staff 1 said Youth A bit Staff 1 before the incident ended.
Reportedly, several supervisors came to help and when the residential supervisor
arrived, Staff 1 left so that Youth A could calm down. Staff 1 said that the Supervisor
called for support during the incident but got no response. Staff 1 said he did not
work anymore shifts at the shelter because it took too long for support to arrive. Staff
1 additionally said that Youth A was spitting at him, so on the third time, Staff 1 put
his shirt in Youth A’s mouth. Staff 1 said this was while they were on the floor and
Staff 2 had directed Staff 1 to do this. Staff 1 said that he didn’t slam Youth A but
noted that Youth A jumped on and over the staff desk, and when he jumped down,
Youth A fell. That is when Staff 1 held Youth A on the floor. Staff 1 said he was
trained in CPI but did not use CPI because the Supervisor was scared and
disengaged. Staff 1 said that he wasn’t familiar with this youth’s behavior and didn’t
know the kid. Staff 1 said only he, Staff 2, and the Supervisor knew about this
restraint.
I interviewed the Supervisor via phone, on 12/21/21, together with the DHHS
Specialist. The Supervisor reported Youth A was sent back from school and was
directed to do his chores and follow the daily schedule for the cottage. Per the
Supervisor, when Staff 1 tried to talk to Youth A about being sent back from school,
Youth A escalated. Youth A was not following directives and Staff 1 removed an item
from Youth A’s room as a consequence. This further escalated Youth A, who tried to
snatch the item (thought to be an MP3 player) from Staff 1 and then began hitting
Staff 1. The Supervisor said Staff 3 was there and she was staffing a youth 1:1, as
well as two maintenance staff were present. The Supervisor said she was also
6

redirecting Youth A. The Supervisor said Staff 1 tried to restrain Youth A from behind
and Youth A kicked Staff 1 in the privates and Staff 1 let go. Youth A then spit at
Staff 1 and charged at Staff 1. The Supervisor said Staff 1 then scooped/held Youth
A against the wall but then they fell to the floor. The Supervisor said she tried to hold
Youth A to help Staff 1, but Youth A kicked her in the stomach. The Supervisor told
the maintenance staff to call for another supervisor. One of the maintenance staff
(reported to be the maintenance manager) helped Staff 1 hold Youth A down by the
arms and legs. The Supervisor said Youth A was punching and spitting and was
“buck wild.” The Supervisor called the police because no one came to help them.
The police arrived about 30-40 minutes later and Youth A was still on the floor and
still struggling, swearing, and kicking. The Supervisor said that she wasn’t going
back near Youth A since he’d already kicked her. The Supervisor said that there was
no other way to manage Youth A. Youth A had reportedly also bit Staff 1 and drew
blood during this incident. The Supervisor said that when the police arrived other
staff and supports came and Youth A got up and acted like nothing happened. Per
the Supervisor, Director 3 told the police not to take Youth A to the hospital. The
Supervisor said that she turned in her keys and left the facility, quitting on the spot.
She said she didn’t write an incident report and didn’t feel the need because “they
don’t do anything to correct the kids.” The Supervisor had been employed there for
two weeks. The Supervisor said that eventually, the residential supervisor came to
help, but that was about 30 minutes into this incident. There was reportedly no
response to the on-call supervisor number.
During email correspondence with Youth A’s foster care worker, some concerns
were reported and noted to be in process of being addressed. One of the concerns
was that Youth A reported Staff Q called Youth A a “white prick” and threatened to
kill his former foster parents. The foster care worker said that Youth A escalates
easily and is easily triggered by other’s incidents. He is working on taking
responsibility for his own actions.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Incident Report, dated 09/15/21, authored by Staff 1. The report noted the
Youth A was not following directions and was put on restriction, so staff were
removing some things from Youth A’s bedroom. Youth A charged at Staff 1
and struck Staff 1 in the face twice. Staff 1 backed up and Youth A continued
to charge at him. Staff on campus jumped in to help deescalate the situation.
Police were called and the director talked with Youth A. Staff 1 documented
bite marks on his own hand but no child injury.
 Staff 1’s termination letter from the human resources department at the
facility, dated 11/19/21.
 Facility policy for Physical Intervention; notes the facility uses the CPI model
for physical intervention.
 CPI manual: does not provide for a floor restraint as reported by the staff.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and procedures regarding restraint. These policies and
procedures shall be available to all residents, their families,
and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation as Youth A was restrained by staff and
held on the floor, which is not permissible within the facility
restraint model, CPI. This floor restraint was reported by Youth
A, Staff 1, Staff 2, and the Supervisor. Additionally, Staff 1 put a
shirt in Youth A’s mouth, which is not a CPI technique.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The staff did not document the restraint in the incident report.
INVESTIGATION:
During the course of this investigation, it was found that Staff 1 did not report on the
use of physical restraint in the incident report. Staff 1 did not provide a reason for not
including this in his incident report when interviewed. It was also found that Staff 2
and the Supervisor did not write incident reports for this incident. Staff 2
acknowledged this and said that maintenance staff don’t have to write incident
reports. The Supervisor reported that she quit the job immediately after this incident
and did not stay to write an incident report.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Incident Report, dated 09/15/21, authored by Staff 1. The report noted the
Youth A was not following directions and was put on restriction, so staff were
removing some things from Youth A’s bedroom. Youth A charged at Staff 1
and struck Staff 1 in the face twice. Staff 1 backed up and Youth A continued
to charge at him. Staff on campus jumped in to help deescalate the situation.
Police were called and the director talked with Youth A. Staff 1 documented
bite marks on his own hand but no child injury.
 Facility policy for Physical Intervention. The policy requires staff to document
the restraint in the incident report by the end of the shift and to include the
details of the techniques used.
 Facility policy for Reporting and Documenting Critical Incidents, revised
09/26/21. The policy notes the following:
8

o ‘… It is critical all staff understand that incident reports must be
accurate and completed in its entirety because it is a legal document.
Additionally, it has an important role with DHHS and its entities,
including the Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL), and Child
Protective Services (CPS).
o Any staff member can complete an incident report. If multiple staff
members witness and unusual or critical incident, all staff members
should complete separate incident reports….
o Staff must complete incident reports that involve:
• Aggressive behaviors that result in physical management.
Critical incidents are of the following specific Unusual Incidents: …
aggression or violence, …
o By the end of the shift:
1. Staff must complete incident reports in its entirety by the end and
turn them in to the designated box within the cottage.
o Proper documentation in writing incident reports:
…The statement must be factual with specific details….
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.159 Resident restraint.
(3) The written policy shall include all of the following:
(c) Procedures for recording restraints as an incident
report.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as the incident report
submitted for this situation by Staff 1 did not document that
physical management was used. Additionally, Staff 2 and the
Supervisor did not write incident reports for this situation.
Documentation of physical management in incident report, and
submission of incident reports by all involved/witnessing staff is
outlined in the facility policy.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The staff who restrained Youth A did not have current training to do so.
INVESTIGATION:
During the course of this investigation, it was found that neither Staff 1 nor Staff 2
had current restraint training. Director 2 forwarded training documentation for these
staff and confirmed that Staff 1 and Staff 2 last completed restraint training in 2018.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Staff training records for Staff 1 noted last CPI training on 09/16/18.
 Staff training records for Staff 1 noted last CPI training on 08/14/18.
 Facility policy for Physical Intervention. The policy requires staff who restrain
to have been trained in CPI and have ‘demonstrated competency in
performing the intervention techniques that are measured and documented
according to relevant professional and state regulatory guidelines within the
previous year.’
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.159 Resident restraint.
(3) The written policy shall include all of the following:
(b) Procedures for the provision of sufficient and
adequate training for all staff members of the
institution who may use or order the use of restraint
using the institution’s written procedures.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as neither Staff 1 nor Staff 2
had completed restraint training in the previous year, as
required in the facility policy. Per the documentation and
confirmation by Director 2, neither staff had completed the
required training in over 3 years.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Cited as Rule 2(f) SI 2021C0108045 with an approved CAP
on 8/25/21
10

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation and 2022C0108005, a first provisional
license is recommended, upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan for the
noted violations.
